accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Series 3 (Journals) is restricted, as are Series 4a (Personal Correspondence) and portions of Series 2 (Manuscripts by Moraga) and Series 6 (Manuscripts by others). In addition, selected items have been restricted and removed to parallel files.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights:
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHY
bioghist.p: Cherríe Moraga, an award-winning playwright, poet and essayist, has received national recognition for her creative and critical writings focussing on racism and classism within the white women's movement, issues of sexuality, lesbianism and cultural and racial identity, as well as homophobia and sexism within Chicano culture. Moraga's involvements as a teacher, gay and lesbian youth advocate, editor, activist and cultural critic have served as a catalyst for her work.

Moraga is perhaps most widely known for the highly-acclaimed anthology, This Bridge Called My Back: Writings by Radical Women of Color, which she co-edited with Gloria Anzaldúa and Loving in the War Years / Lo Que Nunca Pasó Por Sus Labios, a collection of poetry and essays. Her theater productions include "Giving Up the Ghost," "Shadow of a Man," "Heroes and Saints," and "Watsonville : Some Place Not Here." She has most recently written Waiting in the wings : a portrait of a queer motherhood (Firebrand Books, 1997).

Born in Whittier, California in 1952, Moraga attended Immaculate Heart College in Los Angeles, from which she graduated in 1974. Following college she worked for three years as an English teacher in Burbank, California. In 1977 she moved to San Francisco where she attended graduate school in Feminist Studies at San Francisco State University. There, she met Barbara Smith, with whom she was to found the important publishing house Kitchen Table : Women of Color Press in New York in 1981.The Press became a critical voice for feminism from Black, Latina, and Third World perspectives. She has served as an instructor in Women's Studies and Chicano Studies and Creative Writing at San Francisco State University, Stanford University, the University of California at Berkeley, and the University of Massachusetts, Boston.

Moraga received a Theatre Communications Group theatre artist residency grant in 1996, the NEA's Theatre Playwrights' Fellowship in 1993 and two Fund for New American Plays Awards from the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. She was awarded the Outlook Foundation Literary Award in 1991, The American Book Award from the Before Columbus Foundation in 1986, and a New York State Creative Arts Public Service Program Grant for Poetry.
Cherríe Moraga lives and works in San Francisco.

scopecontent.head: SCOPE AND CONTENT
scopecontent.p: The Cherríe Moraga Papers document the life work of an important lesbian Chicana poet, essayist, and playwright of the 20th century. The papers include Moraga's personal and professional correspondence, journals, collected Feminist and Women of Color serials, drafts, manuscripts and galleys, and final publications of her writings, as well as important essays and reviews of her work.

The papers are divided into 19 series: 1. Publications, 2. Manuscripts, 3. Journals, 4. Correspondence, 5. Gigs, 6. Manuscripts by Others, 7. Publicity, 8. Theater Correspondence, 9. Academic Work, 10. Collector's Publications, 11. Publicity, 12. Electronic Media, 13. Essays and Reviews, 14. Photographs, Posters, and Awards and 15. Oversize
Wherever Moraga's original arrangement of materials was encountered, her order was respected.

did.unittitle: Series I. Publications

arrangement.p: Cherríe Moraga has been a prolific writer during the 1980s and 1990s. This series houses a copy of each of her publications, arranged alphabetically by books, edited volumes, and journal publications.

did.unittitle: Series II. Manuscripts

arrangement.p: Manuscript drafts of most of Moraga's volumes are housed in Series II, along with research materials, transcripts of interviews, and correspondence related to individual pieces. Copies of manuscripts contained on computer disks which are part of the collection (Series XII.c) have been made and inculded in this series. These are primarily draft versions of "Watsonville." This series has been organized alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Series III. Journals

arrangement.p: Moraga bound journals and miscellaneous personal writings have been marked for restricted use by the author. The journals are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Series IV. Correspondence

arrangement.p: Moraga's correspondence has been arranged into two subseries: a. Personal and b. Business.The business correspondence contains a large grouping of permissions requests to cite, reproduce, or use her work. Permissions requests have been arranged alphabetically by the author and title of the work her writings are to be used in. Moraga's personal correspondence has been restricted by the author.

did.unittitle: Series V. Gigs

arrangement.p: Following indications from the collection, Series V contains Cherríe Moraga's gig files. Gigs comprise reading requests, speaking requests, interviews, and requests for publication, as well as business correspondence pertaining to her travel arrangements. The series is organized alphabetically by institution (where available) of name of correpsondent.

did.unittitle: Series VI. Manuscripts by others

arrangement.p: Manuscripts by others are arranged alphabetically by author.

did.unittitle: Series VII. Cultural Work

scopecontent.p: Moraga's interest in various social, political and cultural issues is well documented. This series houses her collected research materials, clippings, and articles relating to certain key issues. It is arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Series VIII. Theater Correspondence, 1990s

arrangement.p: Following her own indications, Cherríe Moraga's correpondence regarding the production of her plays has been kept separate from other business correspondence. It includes profiles and resumes of actors, production notes, infomation about various theater companies. This series is arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Series IX. Academic Work

arrangement.p: Cherríe Moraga kept papers and notes written as a student and lecturer, beginning as early as 1970. The papers are organized roughly chronologically into several groups, notably her undergraduate papers, graduate school work, class notes, teaching materials, as well as teaching materials for DramaDIVAS and Indigena as Scribe.

did.unittitle: Series X. Collector's Publications

arrangement.p: Cherríe Moraga collected a small library of feminist, Chicana, and women of color literary publications, written primarily during the 1980s. Most of these publications were from limited runs and are now out of print. The works are arranged alphabetically by title. Notation has been made if a work by Cherríe Moraga is contained in a volume.

did.unittitle: Series XI. Publicity

arrangement.p: Public readings, announcements of new publications, and other publicity related to Moraga's writings are contained in this series. The work is arranged by the name of specific work being publicized.

did.unittitle: Series XII. Electronic Media

arrangement.p: Series XII is arranged into three sub-series: a. Audiocassettes b. Videocassettes c. Computer Disks

Each subseries is arranged alphabetically. Box 5 is currently unavailable to research, pending preservation. Paper copies of every file on 3 1/2 inch floppy disks have been made and housed in Series II. Manuscripts.

did.unittitle: Series XIII. Essays and Reviews

arrangement.p: Writings about Moraga's work, productions of her plays, and interviews with the author are contained in this series. They are arranged alphabetically by type. (critical essays, interviews, and reviews)

did.unittitle: Series XIV. Photographs, Posters, and Awards

arrangement.p: The artifactual legacy of Moraga's career as a writer, this collection is organized into the three categories of the series title.

did.unittitle: Series XV. Oversize
